awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 IEEE Computer Security Foundations Symposium (CSF19)
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal supports student travel to attend the 2018 Computer Security Foundations Symposium (CSF) to be held in Hoboken, New Jersey in Summer 2018. CSF is an annual conference for researchers in computer security, to examine current theories of security, the formal models that provide a context for those theories, and techniques for verifying security. This travel grant will enable career development and learning opportunities for US-based and/or US citizen graduate students. Attending conferences is an important component of graduate school education for our society's future computer security researchers. Students have the opportunity to discuss leading edge research with world-class computer security researchers, and establish networks, connections, and mentoring relationships that will serve them well during their research careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The IEEE Computer Security Foundations Symposium (CSF) is an annual conference for researchers in computer security, to examine current theories of security, the formal models that provide a context for those theories, and techniques for verifying security. This travel grant supported 8 US-based graduate students to attend CSF 2019.

We received a total of 9 US-based applications, 1 without advisor support letter. Of the total of 9 applications, 4 were female. 

Travel scholarships were awarded to the 8 applications (which included the 4 female applicants).  These eight students were able to attend CSF 2019 thanks to the financial support of the NSF travel scholarships. Of these students, 4 were female. Key beneficial outcomes for the students include the learning opportunity of presentations and discussions with worldclass security researchers, and the career development opportunities afforded by networking with computer security researchers and students. A key benefit for the CSF community, and more broadly for the computer security research community, is that the education and generation of generation of enthusiasm in a new generation of researchers that will address important and foundational problems in computer security.

In the exit survey, 5 out of the 8 awardees strongly agree that "CSF2019 helps me to connect with other researchers"; and 5 out of 8 awardees strongly agree that "CSF2019 helps me to identify new research directions". 

 


Last Modified: 12/14/2022
Modified by: Limin Jia
